subject: Re: Asserts after every test

messageBody:
David,

Thank you very much for the reply. I am using JUnit 4 with the @After annotation. I can't quite tell what the issue is, but it seems that maybe IDEA and/or TeamCity is not always reporting all of the errors when there is a multiple exception scenario. I was doing some testing after my original post, and the behavior was inconsistent.

Regardless, am I missing anything here with respect to a way to assert state after any test in a class is run? I've seen many posts where people preach about not asserting in tearDown/@After, but no one seems to offer any alternatives. Is this simply something not currently available in JUnit? If not, I wonder if this is something the current maintainers would consider useful. Maybe an @AfterAssert or something that notes a method that should be run after the test only if the test did not have any assertion failures itself.

Regards,
Paul

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> Can you use JUnit 4? Asserts in @After methods are handled more
> cleanly than in JUnit 3. Especially fun will be 4.7, where you can
> write a single interceptor to be shared across all test classes that
> need this behavior.
>
> David Saff
>
> On Wed, Jun 10, 2009 at 3:30 PM, paulrsnh<paulrs@...> wrote:
> > All,
> >
> >  I have a set of test cases.  After all of these test cases, I need to verify that a particular condition is true.  My understanding is that tearDown should not be used to assert anything, because, among other reasons, if your test case had an assertion failure, it would/could be masked by an assertion failure in tearDown.  However, aside from manually adding calls at the end of each and every one of my tests (which is obviously redundant and error prone and as such unacceptable), how can I assert something after each test is run?
